review.title: Machine Learning for E-mail Spam Filtering: Review,Techniques and Trends
review.abstract: We present a comprehensive review of the most effective content-based e-mail spam filtering techniques. We focus primarily on Machine Learning-based spam filters and their variants, and report on a broad review ranging from surveying the relevant ideas, efforts, effectiveness, and the current progress. The initial exposition of the background examines the basics of e-mail spam filtering, the evolving nature of spam, spammers playing cat-and-mouse with e-mail service providers (ESPs), and the Machine Learning front in fighting spam. We conclude by measuring the impact of Machine Learning-based filters and explore the promising offshoots of latest developments.

metadata.title: Machine Learning for E-mail Spam Filtering: Review, Techniques and Trends

sections.text: We focus primarily on spam filters based on machine learning and its variants and report on a comprehensive overview of relevant ideas, efforts, effectiveness and current progress. The initial background looks at the fundamentals of email spam filtering, the evolving nature of spam, spammers playing cat and mouse with email service providers (ESPs), and the front line of machine learning in the fight against spam. We conclude by measuring the impact of machine learning-based filters and examine the promising offshoots of recent developments. Keywords email · False Positive · Spam · Machine Learning · Spam · Spam filtering.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 Analyzing Temporal Features
sections.text: As a novel solution to the spam problem, [Kiritchenko et al, 2004] used temporal characteristics of an e-mail to conventional content-based approaches to create a richer information space to work with. A simple example of a temporal characteristic retrievable from the message header timestamp is the day of the week or time of the day the e-mail was received. [Hao et al, 2009] presented temporal information in the form of temporal patterns, presented an algorithm for breaking down temporal patterns in an e-mail sequence, and described approaches for integrating temporal patterns into a content-based e-mail classification. [Hao et al, 2009] examined various spatial-temporal characteristics of e-mail senders, and explored ways to derive the reputation of an e-mail sender based only on such characteristics. To improve the state of things, they presented SNac's spatial-temporal characteristics to demonstrate that a spatial-sender classification system is robust in spatial senders.

sections.heading: 3.4.2 SMTP Path Analysis
sections.text: SMTP path analysis works by learning about the "spamminess" or goodness of IP addresses by examining the history of e-mails sent via that IP address. SMTP traffic analysis, combined with traditional filters, improves the accuracy of filters. [Leiba et al, 2005] noted that studying IP addresses is useful and presented a new algorithm for learning the call of e-mail domains and IP addresses by studying the SMTP path used to transmit e-mails. Beverly and Sollins [Beverly and Sollins, 2008] examined a variety of characteristics of the SMTP flow and developed a spam classifier, "SpamFlow," based on the statistical discriminatory power of these streams.

sections.heading: 3.4.3 Behavior Analysis
sections.text: The behavior pattern of an e-mail is "what the sender does when compiling or distributing e-mail." Legitimate e-mails predominantly have normal and meaningful behavior patterns, while spam e-mails exhibit abnormal or even contradictory behavior patterns. [Yeh et al, 2005] considered behavior patterns such as data forgery, time anomaly, relay anomaly, etc., and described them through meta-heuristics and used them as characteristics for the classification task. To detect spam and viruses as irregular monsters in the e-mail, [Hershkop, 2006] proposed some behavioral models, some of which were recipient frequency, group communication, the user's past activity histogram, etc. [Ramachandran and Feamster, 2006] examined spam behavior at the network level and found that most of the spam was received from a small number of regions of the IP address space.

sections.heading: 3.4.4 Analyzing Users Social Network
sections.text: Social networks are very helpful in determining the trustworthiness of outsiders, and thus newer approaches to spam filtering have begun to exploit the interactions of social networks to differentiate between spam and ham. For their social network-based classification scheme, [Boykin and Roychowdhury, 2005] analyzed email header fields to construct a user's social network graph, and classified email messages based on the "clustering coefficient" of the graph subcomponent. The clustering coefficient is very low for spammers while it is high for a network of friends, and the algorithm proved immune to false positives and was able to correctly classify 50% of all emails. [Chirita et al, 2009] and [Golbeck and Hendler, 2004] further developed the idea of creating a social network graph to derive reputation ratings from individuals or email addresses.

sections.heading: 4 Methods for Mitigating E-mail Spam
sections.text: Although there are "social" methods such as legal measures and personal measures (e.g. never responding to spam, never forwarding chain letters) to combat spam, they have so far seen a narrow effect on spam only by the number of spam messages received by users on a daily basis. Technical measures seem to be the most effective in fighting spam. Before machine learning, many different technical measures for spam filtering were used, such as - rules-based spam filtering, white lists, black lists, challenge response (C / R) systems, spam filtering, honey pots, OCR filters and many others, each with its own merits and demerits. Black lists, white lists, challenge response systems, etc., are origin techniques used by renowned filters. sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: Future research will have to address the fact that email spam filtering is a co-evolutionary problem as the filter tries to increase its predictive accuracy, and spammers try to outdo the classifiers. Therefore, an effective approach should find a successful mechanism to identify the deviation or development of spam features. Of all the traditional approaches discussed so far, the only one that has been hugely successful against spam is content-based spam filtering. Fortunately, machine learning-based systems allow for learning and adaptation to new threats by responding to counterproactive measures taken by spammers. No single anti-spam solution could be the right answer. A multi-layered approach combining legal and technical solutions and more is likely to deal a fatal blow to such spam.

metadata.abstractText: We present a comprehensive review of the most effective content-based e-mail spam filtering techniques. We focus primarily on Machine Learning-based spam filters and their variants, and report on a broad review ranging from surveying the relevant ideas, efforts, effectiveness, and the current progress. The initial exposition of the background examines the basics of e-mail spam filtering, the evolving nature of spam, spammers playing cat-and-mouse with e-mail service providers (ESPs), and the Machine Learning front in fighting spam. We conclude by measuring the impact of Machine Learning-based filters and explore the promising offshoots of latest developments.
